title: Impeachment Edges Closer for South Africa’s President, Cyril Ramaphosa
description: Mr. Ramaphosa, who is accused of a cover-up involving millions of dollars in cash, is up against the biggest threat of his time in power.

title: Islamic State Chief Is Dead and New One Is Picked. Both Are Unknown.
description: The group has been reduced from the world’s most fearsome terrorist organization to a low-level insurgency operating in limited parts of countries torn by conflict.

title: The French Baguette Is Granted UNESCO World Heritage Status
description: More than six billion baguettes are sold every year in France. But the bread is under threat, with bakeries vanishing in rural areas.

title: Your Thursday Briefing: Jiang Zemin Dies
description: Plus China’s censors struggle to keep up with protests.

title: Paul Whelan, an American Imprisoned in Russia, Is Hospitalized
description: His family and the Biden administration are worried about his transfer to a prison hospital.

title: Explosion at Ukraine Embassy in Madrid Injures One Employee
description: An employee was slightly injured. Ukraine ordered all Kyiv’s embassies to strengthen security after the attack.

title: Biden Promises Protections for Nevada’s Spirit Mountain
description: But the president stopped short of designating the ecologically and cultural important region, also known as Avi Kwa Ame, as a national monument.

title: South Africa’s President, Cyril Ramaphosa, Faces Impeachment
description: An independent panel found evidence that Mr. Ramaphosa, who is accused of a cover-up involving millions of dollars in cash, may have engaged in misconduct.

title: South Africa’s President, Cyril Ramaphosa, Faces Impeachment
description: An independent panel found evidence that Mr. Ramaphosa, who is accused of a cover-up involving millions of dollars in cash, may have engaged in misconduct.

title: NATO Nations Grow More Receptive to U.S. Pleas to Confront China
description: After the pain of an energy crisis brought on by the Ukraine war, Europe is keen to reduce its strategic vulnerabilities to China, not to speak of other authoritarian governments.

title: Why This World Cup Is Dogged by Corruption Allegations
description: FIFA’s system allegedly fostered bribery, but despite years of investigations and arrests it’s still in place.

title: Xi Jinping Faces Another Dilemma: How to Mourn Jiang Zemin
description: The former president’s death drew tributes from Chinese people at a fraught moment for the current leader, Xi Jinping, who faces widespread criticism of his harsh Covid policies.

title: Physicists Create ‘the Smallest, Crummiest Wormhole You Can Imagine’
description: Scientists used a quantum computer to explore the ultimate escape route from a black hole.

title: Buckingham Palace Staff Member Resigns After Exchange With Black Guest
description: The palace said that “unacceptable and deeply regrettable comments” had been made at a reception. The remarks evoked echoes of accusations made by Meghan Markle, the wife of Prince Harry.

title: Life Without Power in Kyiv, Ukraine
description: After months of repeated Russian strikes, Ukraine’s capital can no longer take electricity, water, heat, cell service or internet for granted. And the hum of generators is everywhere.

title: An Italian Village Hit the Jackpot. Will That Save or Destroy It?
description: Tiny Livemmo won nearly 20 million euros to reverse its decline. Figuring out how to spend it is a big job, but someone’s got to do it.

title: Vitali Klitschko, Kyiv’s Mayor, Says Russia Aims to Destroy Ukraine
description: Vitali Klitschko says of Moscow: “They want to destroy the country from inside.”

title: Ukraine welcomes a U.S. push for energy aid, saying time is of the essence.
Jiang Zemin, China’s Leader After Tiananmen Square Protests, Dies at 96
description: Mr. Jiang, a wily and garrulous politician, presided over a decade of meteoric economic growth in the post-Tiananmen era.

title: A top E.U. official proposes a special court for alleged Russian crimes.
description: President Zelensky, his wife and Ukraine’s prosecutor general all lobbied the international community to support their proposal.

title: U. S. Awards Millions to Move Tribes Threatened by Climate Change
description: Two tribes in Alaska, and a third in Washington State, will get $25 million each to retreat to higher ground.

title: Ukraine Steps Up Push for International Tribunal to Hold Russia Accountable
description: Kyiv is trying to persuade world leaders to prosecute Russian soldiers and top Moscow officials for atrocities in Ukraine.

title: China’s Dramatic Dissent
description: The unrest that has swept across the country is a rare public challenge to the world’s most powerful authoritarian government.

title: Inflation in Eurozone Slows as Energy Prices Ease, but Officials Remain Wary
description: Consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 10 percent in November, down from 10.6 percent a month earlier, the first decline in 18 months.

title: Qatar’s World Cup Narrows Rift With Saudi Arabia
description: The Gulf neighbors were split for years in a bitter regional dispute. Now, the glare of attention provided by the soccer tournament is highlighting their complicated reunion.

title: The Long Odds Facing China’s Protesters
description: Popular protests are more easily begun than ever before, but they are more likely to dissipate, too.

title: Taking Brunt of Lockdown, Migrant Workers Fuel China’s Latest Protests
description: Although security forces have reasserted control in many cities, poor workers could help maintain the pushback against Beijing’s strict Covid restrictions.

title: How Cities Around the US and Abroad Approach Homelessness
description: New York City officials plan to remove mentally ill people from streets and subways. Here’s a quick look at how other cities and countries approach the issue of support for homeless people.

title: In ‘Mandela: The Lost Tapes,’ a Veteran Journalist Finds Himself
description: Richard Stengel, a former Time editor who ghostwrote Nelson Mandela’s memoir, revisits their long-ago conversations for a new podcast.

title: Jiang Zemin, China’s Leader After Tiananmen Square Protests, Dies at 96
description: Mr. Jiang, a wily and garrulous politician, presided over a decade of meteoric economic growth in the post-Tiananmen era.

title: Protests Stretch China’s Censorship to Its Limits
description: Days later, videos of chants and confrontations are still visible on the Chinese internet. It’s a sign of how a groundswell outmatched the world’s best internet control system.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: China has moved to stamp out anti-lockdown protests.
